Whenever boolean operatorsare on the query, you should generally set "searchMode=all" to ensure that all of thecriteria is matched. Otherwise, you can use the default "searchMode=any" that favorsrecall over precision.Example (simple syntax)POST https://{{service-name}}.search.windows.
net/indexes/hotel-rooms-sample/docs/search?api-version=2020-06-30 {   "queryType": "simple",   "search": "budget hotel +pool",   "searchMode": "all" } For more examples, see Simple query syntax examples. For details about the queryrequest and parameters, see Search Documents (REST API).
Strings passed to the "search" parameter can include terms or phrases in any supportedlanguage, boolean operators, precedence operators, wildcard or prefix characters for"starts with" queries, escape characters, and URL encoding characters. The "search"parameter is optional. Unspecified, search (search=* or search=" ") returns the top 50documents in arbitrary (unranked) order.
A term search is a query of one or more terms, where any of the terms areconsidered a match.A phrase search is an exact phrase enclosed in quotation marks " ". For example,while Roach Motel (without quotes) would search for documents containing Roachand/or Motel anywhere in any order, "Roach Motel" (with quotes) will only matchdocuments that contain that whole phrase together and in that order (lexicalanalysis still applies). Depending on your search client, you might need to escape the quotation marks ina phrase search. For example, in Postman in a POST request, a phrase search on"Roach Motel" in the request body would be specified as "\"Roach Motel\"".
